metadata.title: Convert PSI to Bar – Pressure Converter
metadata.description: Convert pressure from PSI (pounds per square inch) to bar using the exact conversion factor, perfect for understanding US pressure specifications in metric terms, equipment selection, and international technical documentation.

introduction: This converter transforms pressures from PSI (pounds per square inch) to bar, enabling seamless comparison between US-standard and metric-standard pressure specifications. It is designed for engineers, technicians, and equipment operators working across regions where different pressure units are standard.

When you need to interpret a pressure specification given in PSI but compare it with metric equipment or international documentation—such as converting tire pressure gauge readings or understanding hydraulic system ratings—this converter provides the exact, internationally standardized relationship.

The conversion is grounded in the precise relationship between the SI pascal (and derived bar unit) and the imperial pound-force, ensuring reliable results for pressure gauge interpretation, equipment specification comparison, safety system design, and compliance documentation.
methodology: The PSI unit is defined as one pound-force per square inch. The bar is defined as 100,000 pascals in the SI system. The exact relationship between pounds-force and newtons is standardized: 1 pound-force = 4.448222 newtons (exactly). Combined with the inch-to-meter conversion (1 inch = 0.0254 meters, exactly), the conversion factor is: 1 PSI = 0.0689476 bar (or more precisely, 1 PSI = 1 ÷ 14.50377 bar).

To convert a pressure from PSI to bar, you divide the value in PSI by 14.50377. For example, 1 PSI ≈ 0.0689476 bar, 30 PSI ≈ 2.0684 bar, and 100 PSI ≈ 6.8948 bar. This factor is documented in NIST conversion tables and is the standard used by pressure equipment manufacturers and engineering references worldwide.

The converter applies full-precision floating-point division internally, maintaining maximum numerical accuracy. Results are displayed rounded to practical precision (typically two to four decimal places), ensuring accuracy suitable for equipment selection, system design, and safety-critical applications.

Because the conversion factor is exact and internationally standardized, this converter produces results that match official pressure conversion tables, equipment specification sheets, and calibration references. The factor has been in use consistently by equipment manufacturers, pressure system designers, and regulatory bodies worldwide.

In critical applications such as pressure vessel design, hydraulic system setup, or compressed gas handling, the numerical conversion should be combined with proper pressure gauge calibration, system testing, and adherence to applicable codes and standards such as ASME boiler and pressure vessel codes.
examples: Example 1 – Automotive tire pressure (US perspective): A typical US tire pressure specification is 32 PSI. Converting to bar: 32 ÷ 14.50377 ≈ 2.207 bar, equivalent to the 2.2 bar specification commonly seen on European tires.

Example 2 – Industrial hydraulic systems: A hydraulic system rated at 3,000 PSI converts to approximately 206.84 bar, a typical high-pressure industrial rating often expressed in bar in European documentation.
Example 3 – Compressed air tools: A pneumatic tool requiring 90 PSI converts to approximately 6.205 bar, typical for industrial pneumatic applications using metric pressure ratings.

Example 4 – Atmospheric pressure reference: Standard sea-level atmospheric pressure is approximately 14.696 PSI, which converts to 1.01325 bar, the standard baseline used in barometer and pressure calculations worldwide.

faqs.question: What is the exact conversion from PSI to bar?
faqs.answer: By international definition, 1 PSI = 0.0689476 bar (or equivalently, 1 PSI = 1 ÷ 14.50377 bar). To convert any pressure in PSI to bar, divide by 14.50377. This factor is the reciprocal of the bar-to-PSI factor and is documented in NIST standards used globally by pressure gauge manufacturers.

faqs.question: Why do different regions use different pressure units?
faqs.answer: The bar is the metric pressure unit widely adopted in Europe, Asia, and industrial applications worldwide, and is easy to work with in SI calculations. The PSI remains standard in the United States, Canada, and some Commonwealth countries due to historical engineering conventions. Modern equipment often displays both scales to accommodate different regional preferences.

faqs.question: How do I quickly estimate PSI to bar in my head?
faqs.answer: A useful mental shortcut is to divide PSI by roughly 14.5 or multiply by 0.069 to get an approximate bar value. For example, 100 PSI ÷ 14.5 ≈ 6.9 bar (actual: 6.895). This approximation is accurate to within about 1%, making it very practical for quick conversions.

faqs.question: Is this converter suitable for pressure gauge calibration?
faqs.answer: Yes. The conversion factor 0.0689476 (or 1/14.50377) is the standard used by pressure calibrators and metrology labs. For critical calibration work, comparison with certified reference gauges or deadweight standards is recommended, as gauge accuracy depends on proper mechanical function and traceability, not just unit conversion.

faqs.question: What is the difference between PSI absolute and gauge pressure?
faqs.answer: PSI can be expressed as 'psia' (absolute, measured from a perfect vacuum) or 'psig' (gauge, measured from atmospheric pressure). At sea level, a gauge pressure reading of 0 psig is actually 14.696 psia. This converter works with both absolute and gauge pressures—just ensure your input is consistently labeled.

faqs.question: How many decimal places should I use in the result?
faqs.answer: For most applications (tire pressure, general industrial work), one to two decimal places are sufficient. For engineering design or system setup, maintain three significant figures (e.g., 100 PSI = 6.895 bar). For calibration or regulatory documentation, follow the procedure specified in your quality manual or standards document.

faqs.question: Can I convert atmospheric pressure readings between PSI and bar?
faqs.answer: Yes. Standard atmospheric pressure at sea level is 14.696 PSI or 1.01325 bar. Barometer readings can be converted directly using this converter, though weather reports typically use millibars (1 bar = 1,000 mbar) or inches of mercury (1 atm ≈ 29.92 inHg).

faqs.question: How do modern pressure systems handle both PSI and bar displays?
faqs.answer: Many modern pressure gauges and digital readouts display both PSI and bar scales simultaneously using dual-scale faces or digital switching. They use this exact conversion factor (1 PSI = 0.0689476 bar) to ensure that readings are numerically synchronized, so 100 PSI and 6.895 bar represent the same pressure simultaneously.

glossary.definition: An imperial unit of pressure equal to the force of one pound exerted over an area of one square inch. Standard in the United States and some Commonwealth countries. Often designated 'psia' for absolute pressure or 'psig' for gauge pressure.

A metric unit of pressure equal to 100,000 pascals (Pa). Widely used in Europe, Asia, and industrial applications globally. One bar is slightly less than standard atmospheric pressure (1.01325 bar = 1 atm).
The SI base unit of pressure, equal to one newton per square meter. One bar equals 100,000 pascals. The pascal is used in scientific and technical documentation worldwide.
Pressure measured from a perfect vacuum (zero reference). Both PSI and bar can be used for absolute pressure values; the conversion factor is the same regardless of reference.

Pressure measured relative to atmospheric pressure. A pressure gauge reading 0 at sea level is actually at 14.696 PSI (1 atm) of absolute pressure. Conversion between PSI and bar applies to gauge pressure the same way as absolute pressure.
